oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ammons's letter describing a South Korean plane crash on Vung Chua
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-page letter describes a plane crash on Vung Chua that killed eight South Korean officers. (The plane, still visible on the mountain, and a nearby monument are pictured in Ammons's photos.) No one knows why the plane was so far from the Qui Nhon Airfield, where it was trying to land. Ammons, describing the current inclement weather, conjectures that the thick cloud cover and heavy rain may have confused the pilot.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Ammons, Christopher D., 1948- ; United States. Army. Military Police Company, 194th
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Christopher D. Ammons was born in Norfolk, Virginia, in 1948. He enlisted in the Army on June 1, 1967, and served with the 1st Infantry Division and later with the 194th Military Police Company. He served two tours in Vietnam, 1967-1968 and 1969-1970.
